Had a sign saying "Athens". I ended having all the way closer to Dallas from a former hitchhiker who used to travel all over the country. 

'Dog', proudly republican and member of the band Black Ice.

Offered me money at the end of the ride, even if I told him he didn't have to.
Gave me his # as well, telling me I have a friend in Texas now, if I ever come back in the area.

Got pulled over by the police during the ride, but for silly reasons. Nothing happened.

Started asking around at gas stations at the intersection. At one of them, a man rudely asked me not to talk to women as I was asking one for a ride. "Because that's how it is in Teexas (Bullshit)

Ended up going on the road because there was a nice shoulder.
A lady (ironic, isn't it ?) stopped to as it was starting raining.
Nice ride, nothing to add.

A first car stopped and someone offered me $100 to go buy a phone for his girl. Seemed fishy and kindly rejected the offer. 

A lady ends up stopping, after she passed me first on the highway.
I was initially planning to reach Angelina State Park to spend the night, but she couldn't drive me that far, so she offered me instead to spend the night at her place and to drove me the day after to Lufkin. 
It ends up being a ride all the way to Alto with a stop, at the Sam Rayburn Dam to show me th

Mostly locals at the gas station who was quite empty, possible to hitch on the road and talking to them as well.
Got a few bucks.
An old man gave me a ride to bring me closer to Highway 90 and have only the traffic going my direction, before he went back to New Orleans.

Slow traffic and nice bystanders to talk with while waiting. 

A Californian couple end up picking me up, giving me lots of life, stock and job advices along the way. They ended dropping me further than planned to help me increase my chances to get a next ride.

Spot reached thanks to Tri-Rail from Miami area. Good shoulder. 

Driver was on his way to Tampa. After an hour of good chat, agreed to do a 1-hour detour to drop me in the city where I was supposed to spend Christmas Eve.

Got here to go through Alligator Alley. 
Little traffic, but might be due to the road works, at the time.

Might have more chance at the previous ramp (Golden Gate Parkway)

A VTC driver going back to Miami picked me up, telling me she was going through this road multiple times a day.
Got offered Fuji Water and listening to her daughter's music, an upcoming famous singer in Brazil!

Good traffic, great shoulder. 

Got a ride from an Uber driver who passed me through a first time. He accepted to drive me all the way to Naples as he was getting there to get more rides.

Nice man, open-minded with whom I had a great discussion over various subjects.

Dropped here in the morning by my host.

Foolishly refused a ride offered as I arrived on the spot because it wasn't bringing me all the way to the Interstate. (Don't do that, there are buses from Downtown Ft Myers who bring you to I75)

Waited another hour before I had a Brazilian joyful Christian who brought me all the way to the Interstate.

Employees from the nearby Love's ask me to leave, but they didn't really know if I was or not allowed to hitchhike at the gas station.

Nice amount of traffic and perfect shoulder to stop. Refused two too short rides before I accepted one from an old woman telling me the next exit has better traffic.
She said she stopped because it was "Christmas"

The Super 8 gas station nearby immediately asked me to leave. 

Fun spot, regarding the traffic lights pace, it is possible to hitchhike at the same time cars coming from East and West.

Got a ride from a very friendly former teacher, who offered me a great chat. 
Stuck after in Fort Myers where he dropped me off, he even ended up hosting me.

As the gas station clerk got out to talk to me, I got a ride to pass the bridge.

Nice man working in polish concrete, he accepted to drop me South on I-75 for me to be in the good direction for the rest of my trip.

2nd or 3rd car pulled over.
Very nice Cuban Uber driver who shared me his tricky and unbearable situation in this country while he was on his way to get a passenger.
After 30', I've been asked to leave the closest gas station. Ended up being picked up shortly after, because I "didn't look American".

Recommend on Hitchwiki.

Police passed by many times and didn't say anything.

Got a ride from a Mexican worker, very nice. He offered me an extra pair of gloves.

Was looking for a ride South to Atlanta, but only locals or people heading North.
Very friendly people, received a bit of cash, got offers to be picked up the next morning and to spend the night at a shelter center in town.

Got kicked out of the Valero on the other side of the Highway after 20' and went to this gas station under local recommendation.

After two hours, a cop showed up and told me it was illegal to panhandle in this county. (idk if he was right, but I don't think so)
finall

Asked for rides at the Shell Station. 
Talked to very nice people in majority, who gave me prayers, warm clothes, food, drinks & cash. 
The gas station employee even brought me hot food at some point.
One of them even offer to host me in his AirBNB if I couldn't find a ride.

Avoid the BP next to it, I got kicked out very fast by the manager.

My rider first gave me $20 before getting me a ride all the way to Chattanooga, TN. 
During the ride, he paid for my hotel room so I could keep go

Plenty of room to stop.

My driver came back and picked me up, because Jesus told her to do so. And because I could only be nice as I was dancing.

Gave me a bag of dates and a few singles.

Dropped here by a local CS.
He told me all his previous hitchhikers got a ride from there on I81.
Great location, but no one stopped, except a policeman.
He told me I wasn't allowed to hitchhike here, but when I said I checked the law and I was fine, he ended up acknowledging his mistake and let me keep going, only asking me to be cautious.

Tried the Shell gas station too, but almost no traffic and clerks not nice.

Got a ride from a local, thanks to a "fun" sign

At the train station, I asked bluntly to the train clerk if he would let me hitchhike the local train. He was very nice and accepted right away, although he wasn't totally allowed to do it.
Always worth to ask !
Got picked up very fast to Fort Payne. Could definitely get further if you're lucky lots of cars passing.
Not a lot of traffic but got a ride to Palm springs
Asked around for awhile got a ride to Las Cruces
Waited in the evening with no luck, camped and got a ride early morning to Jennings
Good traffic long wait short rides
Waited here 2 hours the night before and then camped , got a ride quick the next morning from the sheriff and got blessed with some Cajun food
low-key boring
Decent shoulder , good place to go east , got lucky with someone who would take us north though

Theres a corner with a stop sign where drivers can go up the northbound ramp. Good visibility. The aloha spirit will surely move a driver to lend you a ride if you wait. Someone took me to the Marine base and back.
Got dropped off here, our driver was going to the wide spread panic show, ended up hanging around and got a ride all the way to Coco Beach the next day
Asked around got a ride to the next rest area

good visibility, traffic not too slow not too fast, but the ramp is pretty short. I got picked up by someone who didn't speak english and likely wasn't local, so I don't know how likely a local is to pick you up here, I think I just got lucky.
Illegal but got dropped off here, got a ride pretty quick to clinton
Spot was somewhere around here , not much shoulder but still got a short ride to a better place down the road
Not all that much traffic but got a ride to Mars Hill where it was easy to get someone going to Ashville
Waited for a bit but eventually got a ride a few miles down to a truck stop. Got yelled at by a local though
Hard spot to go south , little to no shoulder, got lucky and a lady picked us up and drove us 20 miles south
Very shady backroads, other than that, my driver was a nice lady, probably in her mid-60s.
Not a great spot but anywhere on 84 in Eastern Oregon you have a good shot of making it across to the Portland area.

Didn't wait too long, but not a good spot in the middle of the city with no gas station nearby. Bunch of cops at the Diner on Sunday morning had me nervous but eventually a woman stopped and took me to Tremonton.
Walked on this gravel road about an hour before I caught a ride. Nice local lady who said the Lord's Prayer when I got out of the car.

After about 5 minutes a cop showed up to inform me that you can't hitchhike the on-ramps since they are technically part of the Interstate. I walked to the grass area by the road right before it peels off to the onramp and got a ride to Lincoln pretty quick. Not a bad experience but I generally found the cops to be a nuisance in Nebraska
Not a lot of traffic getting on the interstate here. Got a ride from a guy who goes to pick up his kids from their mother at the Iowa border.
Waited awhile at this junction. Couldn't figure out if going north to 88 directly would've been better than going west. Eventually caught a ride all the way to Rock Falls.
Ride from a guy in a super cool old Ford Ranchero.
Best spot in Pueblo most likely. Caught a local guy going down to Walsenburg. He told me all about his obsession with the Roswell alien conspiracy.
Not a great spot at all but people in CO are nice.
I 25 is not as happy hitching as the routes farther west in the state.
Picked up by a Navy man going home from his night shift. Offered to drop me wherever within 30 minutes

ended up here after walking i-70 for a little bit, concerned mom got us snacks and drove us what we were gonna walk. got on the onramp and waited a bit before an older man offered to take us to limon. trucker on a day off, seemed to be headed back home from an errand. truly just a day of dumb luck, onramp wasnt very busy, most people would have stopped in bennett for gas

Not sure if this is the best spot, but sure as hell got lucky! Got a lift into Moab to fix my gear and then back and into Canyonlands for a day and along to Green River after. Expensive campsite nearby and not much in the way of food but worked for me!

Not the worst spot, but a cop came and was a bit weird about whether I was allowed to hitch a ride from here (he let me eventually). Great spot to camp out behind the Love's behind a pile of old concrete and crap to stay hidden. Very dusty!
Cop took us to Mathison.
Long wait. Got picked up by a couple of rappers headed to do some DoorDash in Starkville. Large gun in the backseat.
Lot's of nice people at the gas station said they'd like to help but they had to go to work.
Quick ride up an exit from a girl that grooms dogs.
Lots of looks in Lewes. Finally thumbed a ride to Georgetown from a woman who just dropped her kids off at school.
Horrible spot but a Jamaican guy stopped pretty quick. He was on his way to deliver groceries to his grandmother.
Girl stopped in the left lane first to get a look at us, cars swerving and honking, then pulled over and took us down an exit.
NJ is very densely populated so you can expect short rides.
Not a great on ramp. We got a ride on the freeway soon enough. This is where the population density starts to really go up, so expect short rides.
Waited awhile around sunset. Eventually got a lift from a couple of Navy guys headed out to the base in Groton.
Cops pulled up and took us off the interstate.
Lots of cars on the freeway.
Long wait but finally we got picked up by a girl going to Acadia.
Slow highway. Ride from a guy who told us all about Manchester. Complained about the New York transplants but admitted that he was one himself.
Ride up to Arlington, Vermont from a girl with a guitar. She took us to the state park for some jamming and swimming.
German guy took us almost to Vermont. Talked about beer the whole way.
Felt a little odd hitchhiking in the middle of the city but we got a ride all the way to the bus station in Troy pretty quick. All the folks we met in upstate New York were really nice.
Not a bad spot. Plenty of traffic and good enough pullout. Tall grass and lots of ticks -- but that's the case about everywhere in the northeast. Got a ride to Newburgh.
Pretty quiet spot considering the truck stop. Got a ride all the way to PA from an off-duty cop.
Ok lil spot.. not a lot of pull off room but you can make it work.. try to stand by the bridge..

Tried further down to the onramp for a while before switching to this stop and got a ride pretty quick. The people at the k and r across the street are real nice and gave me plenty of ice water. It’s also a good spot to strike up a chat with diner customers and everyone getting on the I-5 gotta go through here.

Spot was good but wait was super long. Finally walked out onto the Interstate. Got a ride to Blacksburg and partied it up. The girl that picked us up had an apartment for us to crash at. Happy hitching in SW VA.
Ride up into VA from a teenager. Great shoulder
Great shoulder but very low traffic. Finally got a ride up to the Interstate from a guy who was headed to play airsoft.
Was feeling disheartened after the cops chased us off the interstate. But then we got a ride from a trucker bound for Manchester. You never know.
Caught a lift all the way to West Memphis with a few Hispanic construction workers.
Ride from a super libertarian ex-cop who dropped us a mile off our route because "Arkansas is this way".
Once the rain finally stopped, we hit the highway. Our driver was begrudging and his wife didn't acknowledge us at all. Some hard traveling in Eastern Oklahoma
I 40 thru east Oklahoma is just a slow hitch. Rides from locals all day. A couple guys who just moved from Missouri.
Not easy for cars to pull over.  Next time I might try at the gas station up the street

Carroll has a lot of people, and a delivery driver offered a ride that I said I'd take but he drove off. Got a ride after 30 right before sunset from a fellow hitchhiker, and he said it's code. Cop pulled into the parking lot right before. Many people were headed home from work or had kids in the car, definitely could be a better spot down the road for a longer duration of visibility as the cars come up.
25's. Got a short ride outside of town. Friendly ppl.
25's. Got picked up by this guy in a Camaro, but he wasn't going far. Could not refuse.
25's. Little traffic, most people look at me like "wtf bro ?". But good visibility and room to stop
25's. Location is ok, people just don't stop. Big wait but good ride
25's. I got lucky I found this spanish guy, not a lot of people were paying attention..
25's Got a small ride here.

Good spot to stop, we hitchhicked from the little traffic island in the middle of the roed, better fisibility and cars can pull over in the parking area. Super friendly people, they took us to they place for the night and then ot Lafayette !
Didn’t bank on a hitch here on a Tuesday. Walked 2 hours down the mountain from hart’s pass before getting picked up.
Usually you can wait for hikers to come down from the Trinity Alps but on a weird day (not weekend) we needed up hiking quite a ways down the road before someone came.
Long wait because we were last in line and had a group of 8 hitching north to Reno
Good location, easy to pull over, but really few people did stop, and only for small rides
end of a 500mi back pack trip out of the woods dirty as can be. Got a ride in out 90min to Silver City NM. Alma has a store but man it is out there, local traffic only.
This is best way south to STL. Do not try I-72E, locals don't take that route. also don't camp overnight if possible, many bums in this town especially along broadway
Not the best place to hitchhike but sometimes that's where you end up. Got lucky at sundown with a ride to Ritzville from a couple of local teachers. They dropped us at the park and we tucked away.

Super low traffic, might not be the best onramp to get stuck at. There was a no hitchhiking sign but the cops didn't seem to care. Got a ride from a guy going to North Bend. He was running simultaneous DoorDash and Uber orders.

Hitchhiked into sunset with no luck. Camped in the sagebrush just outside of town between the road and the railroad tracks. Took us the better part of the morning thumbing before we finally got a ride over the pass with a college professor  who gave us clementines, nut butter, and bread.
Blanca is a nice, quiet town. Cop came by and ran our IDs and then wished us luck on the adventure. Finally got a short ride to Fort Garland in the back of a pickup.
Good spot but slow hitchhiking. The sunflowers are very nice in late summer.
Short ride to Del Norte after a very long wait. This area might not be as good for hitchhiking as other areas of the state.
Not a great spot but got lucky at sunset when a couple picked us up and drove us 3 hours south to our destination. Colorado is happy hitching!
Hitchhiking south out of Jackson is a little tough. Got a ride from a local to a better spot.

Good spot but the vibes for hitchhiking in the panhandle were clearly off. Cops drove by at 10 minute intervals. The couple who picked us up was super chill, talked about art school, Ornithology, and DNA.
Very slow, early morning traffic. Got a ride from a brother and sister headed to Spokane. Big mistake going all the way to Spokane, should have asked to be dropped at the rest area before the city.
The spot was good, but there is a traffic light 400 meters before, and cars drive pretty fast there.

Going to Vegas.
Spot is honestly pretty bad.
People go fast, it's hard to stop anywhere and there's too much distraction for people to really pay attention. 
I got extremely very lucky.
Best strategy is I think to got talk to truckers at the stations
Cars have space to stop, might be too focused on traffic to notice you
Very quiet onramp, but I happened to catch a car there in almost no time!

Seemingly a good spot with heavy traffic, but no luck for me on a Thursday morning. Got a car stopping within 5 minutes, only to get told off for trying to hitchhike. Almost an hour later someone stopped but went West towards Seattle, while I wanted to go East. Gave up at that point.
Good time, but I think I'm a lucky bitch today. 65 mph its way too fast to see and understand what kind of person you are. But maybe people just really kind there idk
Almost dead zone for hitchhiking, but Appalachian trail nearby helps
Everyone think you are homeless and have some drugs in you pocket
Not a great spot, but finally got a great ride with a black guy with no windows (he wore goggles). I'm white and the music switched from Young Dolph to Drake - hopefully a coincidence!
Not a bad spot but the pigs made me drop my sign. Eventually picked up by a young Catholic priest on his way to a holiday in Florida, really nice guy and no funny business.
Picked up by an older couple who put me in the back of their pickup, great fun but not a great spot!

It isn't the best spot for pulling over, but flying right under the No pedestrian sign, there is a parking lot people can pull into. Decent amount of traffic, though id say most people passing by are not headed east. Guy that picked me up wasn't headed east but said he stopped because he has daughters and would want someone to pull over for them.

Decent spot if you're going to dunsmuir. Waited 3 hours and that was the furthest anyone who stopped was going (in that time only 5 pulled over). Not a lot of traffic at this spot anyways, so if you are trying to get further south I'd recommend taking a ride to Dunsmuir and getting on the Amtrak to Sac instead. Of the on ramps in Shasta this one is the best.
Cars drive relativity fast, and bus stop is smaller then I expected, but luckily there is a line for turning right where cars can stop.
Nothing out here besides the two gas stations. Stood by the highway on ramp and thumbed it. Ended up grabbing a ride all the way to Indy
Low traffic but eventually a local country boy took me to Vale. There is beauty in the silent remoteness out here.
Came out of Tyler and needed a ride into a main town with bus routes so I walked 2 ish miles down 904 till someone stopped

This seems like the best spot for going south out of Duluth. There are plenty of cars taking that ramp and there is space for them to pull over. I took the city bus from the north side of Duluth near Brighton Beach to about 3 blocks from here. I could imagine it taking a lot longer than 25 minutes to get a ride because in my experience, the hitchhiking between the Twin Cities and Duluth can be difficult at times.
Lord of local traffic, got lucky and got a ride with a dude willing to go out of his way. People were nice though, made 100 dollars over 4 hours
This intersection is in the middle of nowhere, but I got pretty lucky and got a ride up to Yakima. There is good visibility and room to pull off. Most of the traffic is going west and south.

Obviously, try not to get dropped off here. There is a surprising amount of traffic coming off of 21. You'll get a ride at some point.The bridge on I-90 doesn't have a walkway, so you won't be able to walk back to Vantage if you do end up getting dropped here.
Despite the presence of a truckstop this ramp is pretty slow. That said I got pretty lucky, and didn't have to wait too long.
Weird. Finally got a ride and he drove me all the way to my destination in the cascades.
30 minute wait in the middle of the day. Wide shoulder but fast traffic. I think I got lucky.

Hitching north out of DFW on US-75 is tough. This spot really isn't the greatest, but I got picked up surprisingly fast.

The issue is that there really isn't a good spot for vehicles to pull off. And well also, there is no transit in the area so it's a long walk to get to this spot.

The Costco near Parker rd. would probably be a better option. It's a substantialy shorter walk, and The truck entrance seems like it would offer a good place for vehicles to pull off.

This ramp has a few different truck stops to choose from. I hitched from the ramp here. I may have been better off to hitch off of the highway.

There is a lot of room for folks to pull off.

This area might be ok on a weekday, but when I was there, there was no traffic.

There is tons of room for vehicles to pull off, and a few restaurants near by. I was able to find wifi at the Denny's.
Good spot to go south
Not ideal southbound as its coming out of a curve... Northbound is probably easier.

Cops came shortly after I started hitching. Said it was illegal to solicit a ride at any on/off ramp, and kicked me out. Maybe if you get a ride quick enough it doesn't matter, but the police are not kind to hitch hikers. The actually spot was pretty good, high traffic area and enough room to pull off. With the police presence though, I wouldn't recommend this spot.
Towns in this area are a bit small, so you can mostly rely on long-distance travelers that stop by for a break. I was lucky and didn't have to wait long, but just be patient just in case.
Hit the road at 6:00 AM on a Saturday. Nice lady picked me up and drove me to Garibaldi.
Hassled by the cops in this town, nothing better to do but drive up and down up and down all day. Had to wait nearly 30 minutes for a lift and the cops passed us 4 or 5 times.

Very long wait, no shade and fast moving traffic. Eventually helped because a car broke down and someone came to help them. The guy ended up giving me a ride all the way to where I needed to go, which was super kind, but I think I was lucky
Better to wait in Santa Cruz where traffic is traveling slower, may have waited much longer if we did not get lucky
Spot where cars drive show, and have a spot to stop. Somehow i still had to wait hours.

Nothing worked. We were 2ppl, tried one of us asking at the Buc-ee's, without success. People were not very friendly. And my friend was sticking his thumb out at the freeway entrance without success either. We ended up taking a bus to San Antonio and hoping freight to go further west (Tucson)
Spot is nice everybody heading to the highway has to pass and there is room to stop.
this place sucked for hitchhiking, don’t go to dunnigan ca. stuck here for three days

I got dropped off here by a Sheriff's deputy that was surprisingly nice. He even bought me lunch. 

There wasn't as much traffic as I was expecting, but I was still able to get a ride in a reasonable amount of time.

Probably it was a nice spot, 12 years ago. Now there is a no stopping sign. Was there for about 2 hours and nothing but cops. I made a spot bit righter the route, there is a good on ramp so its just 15 minutes walk and worth it.
Mostly semi trucks on a weekday morning.
Didn't have to wait long .caught a trucker going as far east as I needed..

not the best place to catch a ride...lots of traffic (mostly wyoming plates)...waited 3h until a lift to the TA truck stop a bit east there were many more out of state plates (people going long distance)...people weren't so friendly here...

I waited 5 hours here, but there were some external circumstances. About half the time there was another hitchhiker there with two dogs, so it's possible somebody would've stopped earlier otherwise. And early on I declined a ride because the place seemed good and he was going too short a distance.

Seemed like a good spot to get on the I-40W. There's a big truck stop, plenty of cars, a not-too-bad on-ramp right after a traffic light, so cars are not going by too fast. But I got stuck here for a long time. Now I checked and I see there's a prison in Marion. Maybe that's why nobody stopped...
Standing in the on-ramp didn't work for me, as it's a bit hard for trucks to stop over there. After a few hours I moved to the exit of the truck stop with a sign, and that worked after 25 minutes or so.
